keywords.value: NEW YORK TIMES NEEDIEST CASES FUND

docs.snippet: Fashion may be fickle, but one thing is certain: there will be a lot of bare shoulders this year. Not only on the beaches and at grand parties, but at lunches at nice restaurants, in theaters, at private dinners: where women gather, smooth shoulde...
docs.lead_paragraph: Fashion may be fickle, but one thing is certain: there will be a lot of bare shoulders this year. Not only on the beaches and at grand parties, but at lunches at nice restaurants, in theaters, at private dinners: where women gather, smooth shoulders will be prominent. Designers at all levels -- whether their eye is on women in their 20's, women in their 30's or women who dare not tell their age -- have filled their collections with strapless clothes, and retailers approve. The clothes will begin arriving in stores this month.

headline.main: Shoulders Will Show Up All Over

docs.snippet: An interesting thing happened during lunch this afternoon: the University of Miami football team showed up and actually made some noise.   That may sound strange to anyone familiar with Miami's loud-talking, Bogart-ing reputation. But in the days ...
docs.lead_paragraph: An interesting thing happened during lunch this afternoon: the University of Miami football team showed up and actually made some noise. That may sound strange to anyone familiar with Miami's loud-talking, Bogart-ing reputation. But in the days leading up to tomorrow's Mobil Cotton Bowl showdown between the Hurricanes and the Texas Longhorns, Miami has been uncharacteristically subdued. In fact, it has been Texas, which is celebrating a return to national prominence this season, that has played the role of the brash, loud-talking bully.

headline.main: Texas Drowns Out Miami Going Into Game

byline.original: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: A pause this New Year's Day to update a few of the 1990 Our Towns columns:    In September people on the New Jersey bank of the Hudson were upset to be kept waiting two hours in line for the right to pay $6 a head to take a 10-minute ferry ride to...
docs.lead_paragraph: A pause this New Year's Day to update a few of the 1990 Our Towns columns: In September people on the New Jersey bank of the Hudson were upset to be kept waiting two hours in line for the right to pay $6 a head to take a 10-minute ferry ride to Ellis Island -- particularly when there is a construction bridge nearby, making it an easy walk. As a result, a Congressional hearing in October looked into the bidding that awarded the ferry contract to Circle Line. Rep. Frank J. Guarini has worked out an agreement to keep the bridge in place for now with hopes that it will eventually become a free walkway. He plans legislation to revamp National Park concession bidding. Ferry officials are not retreating; at the hearing, a spokesman said the ride may go to $8.

headline.main: Our Towns; Some Things Change in a Year; Some Never Do

docs.snippet: The Fiesta Bowl, which pits Alabama against Louisville on Tuesday, won't have any impact on the national championship, but it has surely brought focus on the state of Arizona's bruised national image.   The days leading up to the tepidly anticipat...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Fiesta Bowl, which pits Alabama against Louisville on Tuesday, won't have any impact on the national championship, but it has surely brought focus on the state of Arizona's bruised national image. The days leading up to the tepidly anticipated encounter between the 7-4 Crimson Tide and the 9-1-1 Cardinals have been filled with a battle for the "spin control" on the Election Day defeat of propositions that would have made Dr. Martin Luther King's birthday a paid holiday for state workers.

byline.original: By JAIME DIAZ, Special to The New York Times
